choices.text: Remove the tube and looks for spontaneous breathing
Remove the tube fully and bag and mask
Do back physiotherapy to remove secretions

questions.text: An intubated patient in the ICU becomes violent, pulls out Endotracheal tube. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
• In the ICU patients are sedated enough to 'tolerate' the endotracheal tube (this is a very noxious stimulus) and at the same time breathe spontaneously. In such conditions, the patient may sometimes get violent and try to remove the tube. Let us also go option wise and discuss the possible scenarios:
  • Option (A) Remove the Tube and Look for Spontaneous Breathing
  • In the operation theatre: During extubation while waiting for the patient to breathe satisfactorily. If the patient removes tube, most commonly he is capable of maintaining spontaneous respiration.
  • During weaning from ventilator: In these conditions’ sedation is generally stopped and the patient is trying to maintain respiration with some help from the ventilator. This is a common outcome, and we see if the patient is breathing comfortably spontaneously and maintaining saturation, there is no need to supplement respiration/ re-intubate.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used for intravenous induction of anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
• Option (A) Dexmedetomidine and Option (B) Lorazepam
  • Both Dexmedetomidine (alpha-2 receptor agonist) and lorazepam (barbiturate) are primarily used as sedative agents, however both have been used as an adjunct to induction of anaesthesia.
  • The deciding factor between these 2 options can be the fact that dexmedetomidine has been approved by FDA for sedation earlier in ICU setting, and recently in operation theatres as well, and its use for induction of anaesthesia and in operation theatres accounts for its off-label use.
  • Maintenance: with inhalational agents like nitrous oxide, halothane, isoflurane, desflurane, sevoflurane along with opioids, muscle relaxants (if necessary) and most importantly, oxygen.
  • Emergence: May include reversal (most commonly with neostigmine and glycopyrrolate if a muscle relaxant has been used); extubation if an endotracheal tube or an airway device has been used. Basically it involves stoppage of anaesthetic agents to bring the patient back to wakefulness. Adequate analgesia and antiemesis should be ensured for smooth recovery and minimum discomfort to the patient.
  • Postoperative care: Involves monitoring of the vitals, further analgesic and antiemetic agents if necessary.

choices.text: Assess the patient's response, Call for help, check carotid pulse, Start CPR
Check carotid pulse, Start CPR, Call for help, Defibrillate
Defibrillate, Assess response, Check carotid pulse, Maintain airway
Start CPR, Call for help, Defibrillate, Check pulse

questions.text: Which is the correct sequence?
questions.solution: • ADULT CARDIAC ARREST – basic cardiac life support (BCLS)

questions.text: Mask that can deliver maximum O2?
What is the recommended duration of preoxygenation before intubation?
questions.solution: • In between induction of general anaesthesia and securing the airway, there is a period of time called apnea time. This is the time when we attempt intubation/ventilation. It obviously follows that during this time the patient is using reserve oxygen in the lungs. If the intubation/ventilation is difficult, we need more reserve so that the patient can survive the apnea time without significant desaturation. Hence comes the concept of preoxygenation.

questions.text: Least susceptible nerve fibers to local anaesthetics is?
questions.solution:
• For susceptibility to local aneathesia physiology books like ganong gives a sequence of: C > B > A
  • Older editions of anethesia books however gives a sequence of: B > C > A (In general for the nerve fibers of similar type; the larger the fiber, the more resistant it is to the local anesthetic. The size principle fails when myleinated fibers is compared with unmyelinated fibers. Smaller nerves are nore sensitive to the local anesthetics due to their relatively high membrane surface area to axon unit volume ratio. E.g. B fibers are most sensitive to local anesthetic blockage. Amongst the sensory nerve which conducts the cold temperature sensation are blocked most readily. (Ref: Anesthesia and Pain Page 100)
  • Cousins and Bridenbaugh's Neural Blockade in Clinical
  • Miller 8th edition clarifies all previous controversies and gives a sequence of: Aδ > Aδ > Aβ > Aα > B > C

questions.text: Colour of 22 Gauge IV cannula is?

choices.text: Giving colloids and crystalloids ratio of 1:1
Maintaining pH by ensuring acid base are balanced
Maintaining permissible hypotension to avoid bleeding

questions.text: Which of the following is considered balanced resuscitation?
questions.solution:
• 'Balancing the goal of organ perfusion with the risks of rebleeding by accepting a lower-than-normal blood pressure has been termed 'controlled resuscitation', 'balanced resuscitation', 'hypotensive resuscitation', and 'permissive hypotension. ”The goal is the balance, not the hypotension. Such a resuscitation strategy may be a bridge too, but is not a substitute for, definitive surgical control of bleeding ”.
  • 'Early administration of pRBCs, plasma, and platelets, and minimizing aggressive crystalloid administration in these patients may result in improved survival. This approach has been termed balanced, hemostatic or damage control resuscitation
  • Conversely, fluid administration during active hemorrhage may be counterproductive.
  • Risks of Aggressive Volume Replacement during Early Resuscitation
  • Increased blood pressure
  • Decrease blood viscosity
  • Decrease hematocrit
  • Decrease clotting factor concentration
  • Greater transfusion requirement
  • Disruption of electrolyte balance
  • Direct immune suppression
  • Premature reperfusion
  • Increased risk for hypothermia

choices.text: Reduced renal perfusion and reduced urine output

questions.text: During resuscitation of a Norepinephrine was given. How would septic shock patient, you assess that patient is responsive to norepinephrine!
questions.solution:
• Norepinephrine acts at alpha and beta receptors, but it is typically used for its potent agonism
  • Peripheral vasoconstriction increases arterial blood pressure and may cause reflex bradycardia
  • It is frequently the pressor of last resort in supporting systemic vascular resistance. It is used in septic shock to maintain mean arterial pressure

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the procedure per formed with the instrument shown below EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• See MED PLATE 2 KEY
  • The picture seen above is that of Quincke’s cutting needle which is used for lumbar puncture
  • Note
  • Modern disposable single use lumbar puncture needle was given
  • Option (A) false
  • Coagulopathy is a relative contraindication to lumbar puncture
  • Option (B) True
  • Lumbar puncture can be done in lateral as well as sitting position prone position has also been described for the same
  • Option (C) True
  • Bevel of needle faces upwards
  • According to miller’s 8th Ed Pg 1712: The incidence of post dural puncture headache is less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis parallel to dural fibers, i.e. in lateral position
  • Option (D) True
  • The opening pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is recorded while the patient is reclining with the legs extended, the neck straight, and the head at the same level as the spine and breathing normally (not during Valsalva maneuver or breath holding)

questions.text: A chronic smoker underwent laparoscopic abdominal surgery under general anaesthesia induced with fentanyl and propofol. The following EtCO2, graph was observed intraoperatively. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: • The characteristic features of capnogram in endobronchial intubation are dependent on the extent of endobronchial intubation Classically it can be seen as Dual/Bifid/Biphasic waveform. Note the cleft reaching but not touching the baseline however the complete waveform touches the baseline) or it may be seen as Partial Endobronchial intubation. Occasionally. it may be like the one seen in COPD/Bronchospasm (Shark fin appearance).

questions.text: An inotropic drug is to be infused at the rate of 10 ug/kg/min. In a 5 ml vial 200 mg of drug is present. 2 vials of the drug diluted in 250 ml of normal saline is prepared for infusion. If 16 drops = 1ml, What must be the drop rate for a 80kg patient?
questions.solution:
• This question is purely calculation based. However, this is an important calculation since one must know how to set the drip rate when you do not have an infusion pump. This must done meticulously and units (microgram or milligram, per minute or per hour) must not be missed.
  • 200 mg in 1 vial, 200 x 2 = 400 mg in 2 vials
  • Now let us calculate the concentration of the infusate that we have prepared
  • 400 mg in 250 ml NS
  • But, 400 mg = 4,00,000 micrograms (1 mg = 1000 micrograms)
  • Thus each ml contains 4,00,000/250 = 1600 micrograms/ml Now, the infusion rate is 10 mcg/kg/min 800 mcg/min Thus we have to give 800/1600 = 0.5 ml/min
  • 16 drops 1 ml, Therefore, 8 drops/min = 0.5 ml/min
  • Alternative ways in which this question can be asked:
  • Calculate drip rate in a microdrip set
  • Microdrip sets are specially designed for in paediatrics
  • where more fine tuning is important
  • Here, 60 drops = 1 ml
  • In that case, the answer would be 30 drops/min
  • (Note: Most books mention drop factor as 60 for microdrip,
  • while some mention 64. In that case answer would be 32.)
  • Calculate the infusion rate on an infusion pump/syringe pump
  • Commonly, syringe pumps may have a setting where you have to calculate infusion rate in mcg/kg/hour. (note: some may have a setting for/min as well. do read the question very carefully)
  • So, our infusion rate is 800 mcg/min that gives 48000 mcg in 60 min or 48000 mcg/hr or 48 mg/hr
  • Our concentration is 1600 mcg/ml or 1.6 mg/ml That is we have to give at an infusion rate of 48/1.6 = 30 ml/hr

 

Easier way

  • From the first calculation our infusion rate is 0.5ml/min, Thus in 60 minutes we have to give 0.5 x 60 = 30ml/hr

questions.text: Why 100% oxygen has to be given to a patient after recovery from N2O anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
• Diffusion hypoxia refers to the rapid diffusion of nitrous oxide into alveoli at the end of a nitrous oxide anesthetic.
  • During the initial 5 to 10 minutes after discontinuation of anesthesia, the flow of N­2 O from blood into the alveoli can be several liters per minute, resulting in dilution of alveolar oxygen.
  • Nitrous oxide dilutes the alveolar gas and produces a transient decrease in PAO2, and PaCO2
  • In a patient breathing room air, the resulting decrease in PAO2, can produce arterial hypoxemia, whereas decreased PaCO2, can depress the respiratory drive.
  • The combined effects of respiratory depression from anesthesia, reduced alveolar PCO2, and reduced alveolar PO2, can result in hypoventilation and oxyhemoglobin desaturation.
  • In the absence of supplemental oxygen administration, diffusion hypoxia can persist for 5 to 10 minutes after discontinuing a nitrous oxide anesthetic; therefore, it may contribute to arterial hypoxemia in the initial moments in the PACU.
  • This outcome is routinely avoided by providing supplemental O2, for the first 1 to 10 minutes of recovery, together with vigilant attention to respiration.

questions.text: Best Route of drug administration during resuscitation of neonate?
questions.solution: • The preferred route for neonatal resuscitation is intravenous through the umbilical vein. Note that most of the times neonatal bradycardia at birth is due to hypoxia and that securing or mainting airway is all that is required)

questions.text: On giving epidural anesthesia xylocaine with epinephrine was injected. Within 3 minutes the patient had hypotension. Most probable reason for this?
questions.solution:
• The above combination is typical of an epidural test dose.
  • A catheter positioned properly in the epidural space can provide excellent surgical anesthesia, postoperative analgesia, and labor analgesia.
  • Inadvertent placement of the catheter into the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) (intrathecal) or an epidural vein (intravascular) could lead to catastrophic complications.
  • Positive aspiration of blood or CSF from the catheter confirms catheter misplacement.
  • However, the absence of an aspirate cannot rule out whether or not the catheter is actually in the epidural space.
  • An epidural test dose involves injecting local anesthetic to determine accidental intravenous or intrathecal catheter placement.
  • The most popular and effective test dose is 3 mL of lidocaine 1.5% (3 cc diluted to 4 cc, discard 1 cc) with epinephrine 1:200 000
  • Lignocaine has the advantage of rapid onset and offset. Thus, intrathecal catheter can be easily identified but onset of motor blockade within 1-2 min, along with hypotension.
  • Due to its shorter offset, all these changes are easily worn off. The purpose of adrenaline is to detect intravascular placement. 5 mcg/cc adrenaline (total 15 mcg adrenaline) is used in a test dose. An increase in heart rate >10 bpm and SBP >15 mm Hg in 10-30 sec indicates intravascular placement.
  • Thus, test dose avoids complications of accidental systemic toxicity of local anaesthetic which otherwise would have occurred due to injection of bupivacaine through the accidentally place intravascular catheter. Also, if larger doses of Bupivacaine were given without confirming with test dose in an accidental intrathecal catheter, the result would be catastrophic.

choices.text: Extension of head at atlanto-occipital joint
The laryngoscope is lifted upwards levering over the upper incisors
In a straight blade laryngoscope, epiglottis is lifted up by the tip

questions.text: During laryngoscopy and intubation, which of the following is not performed?
questions.solution:
• Maximal head extension: at the atlanto-occipital joint bring the oral axis closer closer into alignment
  • The miller laryngoscope blade is inserted using the Para glossal technique
  • The use of external laryngeal manipulation can improve the laryngeal view.
  • Backward, upward, right- ward pressure (the BURP maneuver) on the thyroid cartilage is most commonly used.
  • Optimal external laryngeal manipulation (OELM) is achieved when the laryngoscopist uses his or her right hand to guide the position and pressure is exerted by an assistant's hand on the larynx.

questions.text: A non-responsive patient is brought to emergency department with no proper history. What will be your first step?
questions.solution:
Scenario 1

  • Patient brought to the casualty by layman and informed that the patient was unresponsive: This is the most common scene in our country where the patient is brought by a relative or a layman to the casualty. Obviously, when informed that a patient is unresponsive, on reaching the scene, the qualified medical officer must check if the patient is indeed unresponsive This involves calling out to the patient once loudly, if unresponsive (this hardly takes any time), second step is activated emergency services with defibrillator. Third step is check for pulse and respiration simultaneously for 10 seconds, and then proceed accordingly.

questions.text: What is the ratio of chest compression and ventilation for all ages done by single rescuer!
questions.solution: • Ref. AHA 2015 guidelines update for cardiopulmonary resuscitation and emergency cardiovascular care

questions.text: All of the following act on neuromuscular junction EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Dantrolene is the only medication that has been shown to be effective in reversing the symptoms of malignant hyperthermia
  • Dantrolene sodium is a hydantoin derivative (1-[[15-(4-nitrophenyl). 2-furanyl] methylenejiminol-2,4-Imidazolidinedione) does not block neuromuscular transmission but causes muscle weakness by direct action on the striated muscle cell.
  • It acts on Ryanodine receptors within the muscle
  • Option (a), (c) and (d) are all neuromuscular blockers/skeletal muscle relaxants.

questions.text: Allergic reactions occurring during the immediate perioperative period is due to administration of?
questions.solution:
• Risk factors for anaphylaxis include a history of atopy, drug or food allergy, multiple operations, systemic mastocytosis, and hereditary angioedema.
  • Common perioperative triggers of anaphylaxis include neuromuscular blocking agents, antibiotics (most commonly beta-lactam antibiotics), and latex.
  • Less commonly, anaphylaxis may be provoked by chlorhexidine, colloids, blue dyes (isosulfan, patent blue V), heparin, protamine, and oxytocin.
  • Chlorhexidine can be found in many products such as skin preparations and wipes, lubricant gels, and impregnated central venous lines and hence all the above should be avoided in patients with documented chlorhexidine allergy.
  • It is rare for opioids or hypnotic agents (barbiturates, propofol, etomidate) to be the source of anaphylaxis.
  • The neuromuscular blocking agents most commonly associated with anaphylaxis are rocuronium and suxamethonium.
  • Anaphylaxis occurs due to IgE sensitisation towards the quarternary ammonium groups in the neuromuscular blocking agents.
  • Cross-reactivity with other non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agents is also highest with rocuronium and suxamethonium

 

Treatment

  • The drug of choice for anaphylaxis is adrenaline. The al agonist effect of adrenaline causes vasoconstriction, which decreases mucosal oedema and hypotension.
  • Its β1 agonist effect increases inotropy of the heart while its β2 agonism decreases mediator release and enhances bronchodilation.
  • The immediate management of anaphylaxis is to stop the suspected trigger, secure the airway, give high flow oxygen, and administer adrenaline in titrated doses with close haemodynamic monitoring

choices.text: Simultaneous administration of an induction and neuromuscular blocking agents
Preoxygenate the patient with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes before intubation
Induction should be done with thiopentone and succinylcholine for muscle relaxant
Cricoid pressure is applied till endotracheal tube has been secured with a cuff

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding rapid sequence intubation (RSI) in a cardiac patient
questions.solution:
• Historically, a classical RSI has employed thiopental as an induction agent and succinylcholine for neuromuscular block. However there are many variants like for example in cardiac patients Etomidate is preferred over thiopental (see table below).
  • Hence this option is correct for non-cardiac patient and false for cardiac patients.

choices.text: Blockade of cardiac accelerator nerve fibres

questions.text: A 46-year-old male was given a subarachnoid block using 12 mg of bupivacaine by anesthetist. After 10 minutes of administration the HP dropped to 72/4 mm Hg and heart rate was 52/min. The level of block was found to be at To. What is the reason for bradycardia in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The Bezold-Jarisch reflex (BJR) has been implicated as a cause of bradycardia, hypotension, and cardiovascular collapse after central neuraxial anesthesia, and in particular spinal anesthesia. The BJR is a cardio-inhibitory reflex and consists of the triad of symptoms, bradycardia, hypotension, and coronary vasodilatation, seen after intravenous injection of Veratrum alkaloids in animals.
  • The Bezold-Jarisch reflex may be a possible cause of profound bradycardia and circulatory collapse after spinal anesthesia, especially in the presence of hypovolemia, when a small end-systolic left ventricular volume may trigger a mechanoreceptor-mediated bradycardia.
  • The Bezold-Jarisch reflex responds to noxious ventricular stimuli sensed by chemoreceptors and mechano-receptors within the left ventricular wall by inducing the triad of hypotension, bradycardia, and coronary artery dilatation.
  • The activated receptors communicate along unmyelinated vagal afferent type C fibers. • These fibers reflexively increase parasympathetic tone.
  • Because it invokes bradycardia, the Bezold-Jarisch reflex is thought of as a cardioprotective reflex. This reflex has been implicated in the physiologic response to a range of cardiovascular conditions such as myocardial ischemia or infarction, thrombolysis, or revascularization and syncope.
  • Natriuretic peptide receptors stimulated by endogenous ANP or BNP may modulate the Bezold- Jarisch reflex. Thus the Bezold-Jarisch reflex may be less pronounced in patients with cardiac hypertrophy or atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A nevallanrane vapourizer can accurately deliver the dose of an anesthetic agent which resembles it in which of the following property
questions.solution:
• Inhaled anesthetic agents are termed volatile because, like other volatile liquids, they possess a high propensity to evaporate or vaporize
  • When a liquid such as an inhaled agent is exposed to air or other gases, molecules at the fluid surface that have sufficient energy escape from the liquid phase and enter the vapor phase. This process is known as an evaporation which is purely a surface phenomenon

questions.text: The relation of age and MAC requirements are represented correctly in which of the following:
questions.solution: Anesthetic requirements is smaller for preterm than for term neonates and smaller for term neonates than 3 month olds. Infant have a higher MAC than that of older children or adults. The reasons for these age related differences in MAC are not known

questions.text: A drug that undergoes Hoffmann elimination is?
questions.solution:
Atracurium is a new neuromuscular blocking agent which has an unique mode of elimination by spontaneous degradation in slightly alkali solution, according to the Hofmann elimination..

Because of spontaneous degradation of atracurium in plasma, its kinetics are theoretically independent of renal and liver functions. Only a slight increase of distribution volumes can be seen in very severe renal/hepatic failure. Atracurium pharmacokinetics could theoretically be modified by some modifications of acid-base equilibrium or alterations of thermoregulation

questions.text: A patient with diarrhea and severe dehydration requires rapid infusion of IV fluids. Which colour of canula will you prefer?
questions.solution:
• Ref: Oxford American handbook of dinical examinations and Practical skills By Elezabeth Burns Ch 18, Bailey 25th ed page 291 Indirect repeat from AIIMS NOV 2015 (Calibre of the cannula was asked)
  • ACLS guidelines recommend securing IV access by two large bore cannulae (14-16 G) in patient needed resuscitation

questions.text: In case of massive bleeding during surgery which size of IV cannula is used?
questions.solution:
• Ref: Oxford American handbook of clinical examinations and Practical skills By Elezabeth Burns Ch 18, Bailey 25th ed page 291
  • ACLS guidelines recommend securing IV access by two large bore cannulae (14-16 G) in patient needed resuscitation
  • In case of a massive bleeding, we would like to resuscitate the patient with rapid infusion of IV fluids. This can be effectively achieved with a higher gauge cannula. Always remember, higher the Gauge, smaller the cannula

questions.text: A patient was in surgery when following Capnography picture was noticed. What is the next most appropriate step?
questions.solution:
• See table of Copnography and table of some important Capnography in Anesthesia AIIMS Nov 2016
  • The cleft in the capnograph is due to patients own respiratory efforts due to inadequate muscle relaxamts. The next most appropriate is to increase the muscle relaxant.
  • A good alveolar plateau greatly increases the chances that the end tidal reading is a reliable estimate of the alveolar level. The angle between the end of Phase III and the descending limb of the capnogram is called the beta angle. Normally it is approximately 90°. The angle will be increased with rebreathing. Another possible cause of an increased beta angle is a prolonged response time compared with the respiratory cycle time, particularly in children. The angle will be decreased if the slope of Phase III is increased.

questions.text: Tip of cuff of LMA placed over Point marked as A in the device shown in the picture is placed out
questions.solution: • The device shown in the picture is Proseal LMA which has internal drainage (gastric) tube which is lateral to the airway tube and ends at the tip of the mask for aspiration of gastric contents in the event of passive regurgitation and hence the tip is placed just above the esophageal opening.

choices.text: Grey body black and white shouder

questions.text: What is true about medical oxygen cylinder?
Ideal site for measuring temperature during anesthesia
questions.solution:
• 'Tympanic-membrane temperature has been suggested as the most ideal core temperature monitoring site'.
  • Remember that Tympanic membrane is not the most commonly used site to measure core body temperature due to technical difficulties, In patients with endotracheal tubes, monitoring of esophageal temperature is more reliable than rectal temperature and more practical than tympanic temperature.
  • Because of difficulties associated with obtaining appropriate sized thermistors and reports of tympanic membrane perforation, the clinical use of continuous intraoperative temperature measurement is limited.
  • 'The anatomical position of the tympanic membrane is deep within the skull and separated from the internal carotid artery by only the narrow air-filled cleft of the middle ear and a thin shell of bone, making it an attractive site for temperature measurements. The tympanic membrane and the hypothalamus share a common blood supply, so measuring temperature at this site may reflect thermal information at the primary site of thermoregulation'.

choices.text: Ketamine followed by intubation and GA
Propofol followed by intubation and GA

questions.text: A pregnant female presents with lacenta previa, bleeding Ind systolic BP of 85 mm Hg, induction and maintenance of anesthesia for cesarean section is done by
questions.solution:
• Option (A) Ketamine followed by GA and intubation
  • Ketamine (1-2 mg/kg) is known to have sympathomimetic effects and raises blood pressure. This followed by GA and intubation (Assuming muscle relaxant has been given, however not mentioned in the option) seems like a good option to maintain blood pressure even after induction of anaesthesia. However, we must remember that in hypovolemic patients there is maximal vasoconstriction, ketamine in these cases is not likely to cause further vasoconstriction but causes myocardial depression instead. Thus, it is mandatory to resuscitate with fluids and blood even if we are using ketamine for induction.

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used for which procedure?
questions.solution:
• NOTE
  • Modern disposable single use lumbar puncture needle was given.

questions.text: Which anti-cholinergic drug is most commonly used pre-aesthetic medication
questions.solution:
• The addition of a muscarinic anticholinergic drug to anesthetic premedication for decreasing secretions and preventing harmful vagal reflexes was mandatory in the era of ether anesthesia, but it is less important with modern inhaled agents.
  • Routine preoperative use of these drugs as antisialagogues continues in some pediatric and otorhinolaryngologic cases, along with administration of ketamine or when fiberoptic intubation is planned.
  • Atropine has a tertiary structure that easily crosses the blood-brain barrier. CNS effects have been seen with the relatively large doses (1-2 mg). In contrast, one of the synthetic antimuscarinic drugs, glycopyrrolate, does not cross the blood-brain barrier because of its quaternary structure and has gained popularity for this use.
  • Atropine and glycopyrrolate both can be used as premedication. However, Glycopyrrolate is the more frequently used premedication used, amongst the handful situations where premedication is actually used. Earlier, Atropine was ad ministered in neonates who have a higher vagal tone. How ever, this is not frequently practiced.

questions.text: Which structure, when pierced, causes First snap Resistance during epidural anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Identification of the increase of resistance (ligamentum flavum)

As soon as the point of the needle has engaged the ligamentum flavum, a feeling of a greater increase of resistance, often associated with a 'crunch', is perceived. The advancement of the needle is immediately stopped.

questions.text: Which of these anesthetic agents is contraindicated in a patient with coronary artery disease with pulse rate of 48/min, low BP and decreased myocardial contractility on Echo
questions.solution: • Dexmedetomidine is an alpha 2 agonist, and causes a decrease in central sympathetic outflow. Hence, it causes bradycardia and hypotension. Thus, we would like to avoid this agent in the given scenario of pre-existing hypotension and bradycardia in a patient with coronary artery disease, in whom hypotension should be prevented in order to maintain cardiac perfusion increased workload. Also, the sympathetic system might be maintaining the BP in the above patient, and sympatholysis may cause profound hypotension.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle relaxant can be used in a patient with high bilirubin of 6 mg/dL and serum creatinine of 4.5 mg/d2
questions.solution:
• Atracurium undergoes Hoffman's elimination as well as degradation by esterases, and thus is not dependent on kidneys for elimination. Hence, it can be safely given in patients with renal disease.

 

Anaesthetics Sale in Renal Failure:

questions.text: Which anesthesia agent can cause pain an IV administration?
questions.solution:
• Propofol is known to cause pain on injection because it is formulated in a oil based preparation
  • Numerous strategies have been proposed to reduce pain on injection, of which the most effective are the use of a large antecubital vein or pretreatment with lidocaine in conjunction with venous occlusion.
  • Alternative preparations of propofol, such as those containing bisulfite or comprising medium- and long chain triglycerides, have had a modest or negligible effect in reducing injection pain, whereas some formulations significantly increase pain.
  • The addition of lidocaine remains more effective at reducing pain than the choice of propofol formulation.

 

NOTE

  1. Drugs causing pain on IV injection: Propofol, Etomidate
  2. Thiopentone causes severe pain on intra Arterial

questions.text: Which of the following combination can be used for day care surgery
Which of the following agent is used in day care surgery?
questions.solution: Propofol has been the major contributory anesthetic agent in the rapid evolution of day-care surgery due to its superior recovery characteristics. Infusions of propofol, remifentanil, and dexmedetomidine have galvanized the advancements made in ambulatory anesthesia, especially in short surgical procedures

questions.text: The names Bethune and Brethren are associated with which of the following monitoring devices!
questions.solution: • In 1965, end-tidal CO2 monitoring was introduced by Bethune and Brechner, followed in 1968 by the introduction of precordial Doppler ultrasonography by Maroon

questions.text: An eye surgery was performed wing propofol as the Intravenous anaesthetic agent and succinylcholine as the muscle relaxant. Recovery from anaesthesia was uneventful However the patient complains of pain in the muscles. Which of the following is the likely reason for this?
questions.solution: • Succinyl choline is a depolarizing agent that causes twitches and then muscle relaxation. It is associated with postoperative myalgias. This can be easily managed with regular postoperative analgesic agents.

questions.text: All of the following are methods for improving oxygenation using a ventilator, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• If we read the question carefully, except ECMO, all other options involve the use of a ventilator. Extra corporeal membrane oxygenation, on the other hand, is a veno-venous technique that bypasses the lungs, and is not a ventilator strategys.
  • Ventilator is capable of causing lung trauma. In conditions especially like ARDS, all the above therapies are beneficial in improving oxygenation. The rationale for use of each of the following is given below:
  • Option (A)
  • In patients with severe hypoxemic and/or hypercapnic respiratory failure, extracorporeal lung support (ECLS) techniques, including extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), have been considered to be possible rescue therapies. The aim of this strategy is to overcome severe hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis while keeping the lung completely at rest. Thus, low tidal volume (5-7 ml/kg) and high PEEP improves oxygenation.

questions.text: A patient of head injury is intubated and ventilated. Which would be the ideal mode of ventilation in him?
questions.solution: • Continuous mandatory ventilation or controlled mechanical ventilation (CMV) is usually employed in most severe head trauma. The volume-controlled CMV gives you optimal control over your minute volume. If you are trying to maintain a very narrow CO2, range in a paralysed sedated head injury patient, this would be a good choice. Of course, if they wake up, they will start fighting the ventilator, coughing against it, as it obstinately blows unwanted breaths into their lungs. It is an uncomfortable mode of ventilation for anyone who is even slightly awake. These patients are under heavy sedation and neuromuscular blocking agents are often used to prevent the increase in ICP caused by coughing and fighting the ventilator. Also, an increase in PaCO2, will increase intracranial pressure by increasing blood flow, so it is best to control ventilation during critical periods.

questions.text: What is the appropriate size of LMA for an average adult patient weighing 50 kg is?
questions.solution:
According to a previous study regarding the optimal LMA size selection, the sex-related formula (size 4 for females and size 5 for males) was more preferable1 than the manufacturer weight-based recommendations (size 3 for 30–50 kg; size 4 for 50–70 kg; and size 5 for >70 kg).

See ANESTH PLATE 7 KEYS

questions.text: At supra-MAC concentrations, anesthetics lead to shift of EEG wave from?
questions.solution:
• Minimum alveolar concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at atmospheric pressure is that required to prevent movement in response to a supramaximal noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects.
  • MAC is analogous to the plasma EC50 (concentration for 50% effect) for intravenous anesthetics.
  • MAC-BAR (50% more than MAC), which is the concentration required to block adrenergic response to nociceptive stimuli.
  • MAC-awake (0.15-0.5 MAC), the concentration required to block voluntary reflexes and control perceptive awareness.
  • Supra-MAC Anesthetic Concentrations: Large doses of anesthetics shift the EEG from theta to delta with increased slowing and finally a decrease in amplitude with burst suppression and ultimately an isoelectric.
  • Sub-MAC concentrations show 'WAR' pattern-wide-spread anterior rhythm-in lower beta or alpha range.
  • Trapezius squeeze and tetanic stimulus may be considered as non invasive stimuli equivalent to surgical stimulus. The advantage is that the former can be repeated
  • Tracheal intubation is the most painful stimulus (more than even surgical excision) and requires the maximum MAC.

choices.text: Loss of consciousness to the onset of spontaneous respiration
From onset of regular respiration to cessation of spontaneous breathing

questions.text: The plane of surgical anesthesia during ether anesthesia is defined as?
questions.solution:
• Stage 1 (Stage of analgesia or disorientation)
  • Stage 2 (Stage of excitement or delirium)
  • Stage 3 (Stage of surgical anesthesia)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not affect absorption and secretion of cerebrospinal fluid?
questions.solution:
• Furosemide (decreases CSF production), acetazolamide (decreases CSF production), digoxin, corticosteroids (decrease CSF formation increase absorption).
  • Nitrous oxide does not affect CSF production or absorption • Thiopentone and etomidate decrease CSF production and increase absorption, while ketamine reduces absorption with no effect on production.
  • In general, anesthetic drugs suppress cerebral metabolic rate, with ketamine and N O being notable exceptions.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anesthetic agents is contraindicated in epileptic patients posted for general anesthesia?
questions.solution: • Ketamine can elicit seizures in patients with an epileptic diathesis as it further increases ICP and also causes delerium and hallucinations.

questions.text: Lithium should be stopped how many days before surgery?
questions.solution:
• Miller states: 'Discontinuation of Lithium has been associated with suicide risk'. Current guidelines suggest to continue all psychiatric medications till the date of surgery, however for the sake of this particular question read following lines.
  • Lithium does not need to be stopped for minor surgery; it has been suggested that it should be stopped 24-48 hours before major surgery but this is disputed. From a psychiatric perspective interruption in lithium therapy are bad for the patient since there is good evidence that they lead to a worse course of affective disturbance than if the patient was left untreated. Lithium prolongs both depolirising and non-depolarising muscle relaxant. The effect of Lithium on other classes of anesthetic agents have not been studied. It may also reduce anaesthetic requirements as it blocks brain stem release of noradrenaline and dopamine. Drugs which may exacerbate renal impairment should be used with caution, including NSAIDs which as mentioned above may also increase lithium levels. Careful attention should be paid to fluid and electrolyte balance. If discontinued, lithium should be restarted 24 hours postoperative
